entry.title: Webmention on Google Cloud Run
entry.content:
I just published webmention-run, a Google Run application written in Go that implements Webmention. I‚Äôm now using this to handle webmentions on bitworking.org. Given the generous free quota for Google Run I don‚Äôt expect this to cost me anything. This is on top of using Firebase Hosting to host the static (Jekyll) parts of my blog, which is also effectively free.

Another awesome feature is that both services will provide SSL certificates; in my case Firebase Hosting provides the cert for https://bitworking.org, and Google Cloud Run provides the SSL cert for the subdomain where my instance of webmention-run is running, which is the subdomain https://webmention.bitworking.org.

entry.title: The Great Famine of 1315-1317
entry.content:
Great Famine

The Great Famine of 1315-1317 only lasted two years, was no where close to the change in climate that we are looking in the face right now, and it wiped out 10-25% of the population.

To provide some measure of relief, the future was mortgaged by slaughtering the draft animals, eating the seed grain, abandoning children to fend for themselves (see ‚ÄúHansel and Gretel‚Äù) and, among old people, voluntarily refusing food for the younger generation to survive.

One of the things that frightens me most about climate change is that small changes can have drastic affects and institutions can unravel much more quickly than anyone imagines. My fear is that by the time things get bad enough that we need to try things like geoengineering our institutions will have fallen apart and we‚Äôll be incapable of launching such efforts.

entry.title: simplifying income
entry.content:
Bill Gates

In terms of revenue collection, you wouldn‚Äôt want to just focus on the ordinary income rate, because people who are wealthy have a rounding error of ordinary income.

I would love to see the U.S. do away with categories of income (income, earned interest, capital gains, etc) and make it all just one bucket and tax that at a progressive rate.

entry.title: CEO Pay
entry.content:
I‚Äôve said the Harvard MBA is the most second most damaging thing to happen to business in the last 40 years. I might have to clarify that to ‚Äúthe myth of the Harvard MBA is the second most damaging thing to happen to business in the last 40 years‚Äù.

We found no statistically significant alphas ‚Äî despite testing every possible school with a reasonable sample size. MBA programs simply do not produce CEOs who are better at running companies, if performance is measured by stock price return.

But if there is no evidence that stock returns are attributable to CEOs, then what justification is there for their stratospheric pay? How much longer will investors and boards be fooled by randomness and hollow credentialism?

Oh, and the first most damaging thing to happen to business in the past 40 years? The Chicago School of Economics.

entry.title: More TMI recovery stories
entry.content:
This is another story from my recovery that might be TMI for some people. Read with caution, or skip.

So while describing my initial hospitalization I mentioned an open question:

What exactly my anus is supposed to be doing for those three months is a question I forget to ask.

And now I know from the questions and comments I‚Äôve received that many of you are curious too.

The answer turns out to be ‚Äúnothing much‚Äù for most of the time, with occassional bouts of Phantom Limb sensation.

Now the ‚Äúphantom limb‚Äù in this case is my large intestines, which are no longer hooked up to my rectum. The sensation they are missing is the pressure that comes when stool builds up in the colon, which in turn triggers the sensations of ‚Äúneeding to go‚Äù.

So one or two times a day I get the sensation of ‚Äúneeding to go‚Äù. I logically know that‚Äôs an impossibility, but apparently my rectum is not swayed by logic, so I had to look for alternative methods of getting the sensation to go away. It turns out there is one way to get it to go away and that‚Äôs to go and sit on the toilet as if I were having a bowl-movement. And I realize, as I sit here, on the toilet, not having a bowl-movement, that what I‚Äôm really doing in playing ‚Äúmake pretend‚Äù for my rectum. And it works!

I wonder if my rectum will be as grateful as my kids are for all the time I spent playing ‚Äúmake pretend‚Äù with them?
entry.summary: This is another story from my recovery that might be TMI for some people. Read with caution, or skip.
